editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Sir Gyles Goosecap knight. A comedy presented by the Chil: of the chapel.
At London. Printed by John Windet for Edward blunt. 1606.

list.item: Eugenia, a widow, and a noble lady.
Hyppolita, lady-virgins, and companions to Eugenia ▪
Penelope, lady-virgins, and companions to Eugenia ▪
Momford, a noble man, uncle to Eugenia.
Fowlewether , a French affected traveller, and a captain.
Sir Giles Goosecap ▪ a foolish knight.
Sir Cuthbert Rudesby, a blunt knight.

div.head: Scaena prima

sp.speaker: Bullaker.
sp.p: This is the countess Eugenia's house I think, I can never hit of these same English city houses, though I were born here: if I were in any city in France, I could find any house there at midnight.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: These two strange hungry knights (Will) make the leanest trenchers that ever I waited on.
A plague on them Jack, they leave us no fees at all, for our attendance, I think they use to set their bones in silver they pick them so clean, see, see, see Jack what's that?

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: A my word (Will) 'tis the great baboon, that was to be seen in Southwark.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Is this he? gods my life what beasts were we, that we wood not see him all this while, never trust me if he look not somewhat like a man, see how prettily he holds the torch in one of his forefeet, where's his keeper 〈◊〉 owe, is he broke loose?

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: Hast ever an apple about thee (Will) we'll take him up sure, we shall get a monstrous deal of money with him.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: That we shall yfath boy, and look thou here, here's a red cheeked apple to take him up with.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Excellent fit a my credit, let's lay down our provant, and to him.

sp.speaker: Bul ▪
sp.p: I'll let them alone a while.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Give me the apple to take up Jack, because my name is Jack.

sp.speaker: Wil
sp.p: Hold thee Jack, take it.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Come Jack, come Jack, come Jack.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I will come to your sir, I'll jack ye a my word, I'll jack ye.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: God's me he speaks Jack, oh pray pardon us sir ▪

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Out ye mopede monkeys can ye not know a man from a Marmoset, in these frenchified days of ours? nay I'll jackefie you a little better yet.

sp.speaker: Both,
sp.p: Nay good sir, good sir, pardon us ▪

sp.speaker: Bul ▪
sp.p: Pardon us, out ye homebred peasants, plain English, pardon us, if you had parled, and not spoken, but said pardonne moy ▪ I wood have pardoned you, but since you speak, and not parley, I will cudgel ye better yet.

sp.speaker: Ambo
sp.p: O pardonne moy monsieur.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Bièn je vous remercy, there's pardon pour vous sir now.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Why I thank ye for it sir, you seem to be a squire of our order sir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Whose page might you be sir.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I am now the great French traveler's page ▪

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Or rather the French Traveler's great page. Sir, on, on

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Heighted captain Foulweather, alias commendations; whose valours within here at supper with the countess Eugenia, whose proper eaters I take you two to be.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: You mistake us not sir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: This captain Foulweather, alias commendations (Will) is the gallant that will needs be a suitor to our countess

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Faith and if Foulweather be a welcome suitor to a fair lady, has good luck.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
O sir, beware of one that can shower into the ▪ laps of ladies, captain Foulweather? why he's a
captinado, or captain of captains, and will lie in their joints that give him cause to work upon them so heavily, that he will make their hearts ache I warrant him ▪ captain Foulweather? why he will make the cold stones sweat for fear of him, a day or two before he come at them. Captain Foulweather? why he does so domineer, and reign over women.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: A plague of captain Foulweather I remember him now Jack, and know him to be a dull moist brained ass.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: A Southern man I think.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: As fearful as a hare, and 'a will lie like a lapwing, and I know how he came to be a captain, and to have his surname of commendations.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: How I prithee will?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Why sir he served the great lady Kingcob, and was yeoman of her wardrobe, and because 'a could brush up her silks lustily, she thought he would curry the enemy's coats as soundly, and so by her commendations, he was made captain in the low countries.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Then being made captain only by his lady's commendations, without any worth also of his own, he was ever after surnamed captain commendations?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I sir right, but if he had not said right, my captain should have taken no wrong at his hands, nor yours neither I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: What are those two knights names, that are thy captains comrades, and within at supper with our lady?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: One of their names sir, is, sir Gyles Goosecap, the others sir cut. Rudseby.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Sir Gyles Goosecap what's he a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I that he is at least if he be not a noble man, and his chief house is in Essex.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: In Essex? did not his ancestors come out of London

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p:
Yes that they did sir, the best Goosecaps
in England, comes out of London I assure you.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: I but sir these must come into it before they come out on't I hope, but what countryman is sir Cutt. Rudeby?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: A Northern man, or a Westernman I take him, but my captain is the emphatical man; and by that pretty word emphatical you shall partly know him; for 'tis a very forcible word in troth, and yet he forces it too much by his favour; marry no more than he does all the rest of his words; with whose multiplicity often times he travels himself out of all good company.

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: Like enough; he travailed for nothing else.

sp.speaker: Wil
sp.p: But what qualities haunt sir Gyles Goosecap now sir?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Sir Gyles Goosecap has always a death's head (As it were) in his mouth, for his only one reason for every thing is, because we are all mortal; and therefore he is generally called the mortal knight; then hath he another pretty phrase too, and that is ▪ he will tickle the vanity ant still in every thing and this is your summa totalis of both their virtues.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: 'Tis enough, 'tis enough, as long as they have land enough, but now muster your third person afore us I beseech you,

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: The third person and second knight blunt sir cut. Rudesby, is indeed blunt at a sharp wit, and sharp at a blunt wit a good bustling gallant talks well at rovers; he is two parts soldier; as slovenly as a Swisser, and somewhat like one in face too; for he wears a bush beard will dead a cannon shot better than a woolpack: he will come into the presence like your Frenchman in foul boots ▪ and dares eat garlic as a preparative to his courtship; you shall know more of him hereafter; but good wags let me win you now, for the geographical parts of your ladies in requital.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p:
That you shall sir, and the hydrographical too and you will; first my lady the widow, and countess
eugenia, is in earnest, a most worthy lady, and indeed can do more than a thousand other ladies can do I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Bul
sp.p: What's that I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Marry sir, he means she can do more than sleep, and eat and drink; and play at noddy, and help to make herself ready.

sp.speaker: Bul
sp.p: Can she so?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: She is the best scholar of any woman but one in England, she is wise and virtuous,

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Nay she has one strange quality for a woman besides, though these be strange enough that he has reckoned.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: For god's sake what's that?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: She can love reasonable constantly, for she loved her husband only, almost a whole year together.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: That's strange indeed, but what is your fair lady sir?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: My lady sir, the lady Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: That is as chaste as ever was Hippolytus.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: (True my pretty parenthesis) is half a maid, half a wife, and half a widow.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Strange tale to tell; how canst thou make this good my good assumpsit.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
Thus sir, she was betrothed to a gallant young gentleman that loud her with such passion and admiration that he never thought he could be so blessed as to enjoy her in full marriage, till the minister was marrying them, and even then when he was saying I Charles take thee Hippolita; with extreme joy he began to look pale, then going forwards saying to my wedded wife, he looked paler, and, then pronouncing, for richer for poorer as long as we both shall live, he looked extreme pale; now sir when she comes to speak her part, and said, I Hippolyta take thee Charles, he began to faint for joy, then saying to my wedded husband, he began to sink, but then going forth too for better for worse, he
could stand no longer but with very conceit it seemed, that she whom he tendered as the best of all things, should pronounce the worst, and for his sake too, he sunk down right, and died suddenly: and thus being half married, and her half husband wholly dead, I hope I may with discretion affirm her, half a maid, half a wife, and half a widow; do ye conceive me sir?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: O lord sir, I devour you quick; and now sir I beseech you open unto me your tother lady, what is she?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: I'll answer for her, because I know her ladyship to be a perfect maid indeed.

sp.speaker: Bul
sp.p: How canst thou know that?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Passing perfectly I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: By measuring her neck twice, and trying if it will come about her forehead, and slip over her nose?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: No sir no, by a rule that will not slip so I warrant you, which for her honour's sake I will let slip unto you, gods so Jack ▪ I think they have supped.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: By'r lady we have waited well the while.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Well though they have lost their attendance, let not us lose our suppers Jack.

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: I do not mean it, come sir you shall go in and drink with us i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Pardonne moy monsieur.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: No pardoning in truth sir,

sp.speaker: Bul
sp.p: Je vous remercy de-bon ceur.

div.stage: Enter Goosecap Rudesby Fouleweather Eugenia Hippol. Penelope, Wynne.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: A plague on you sweet ladies, 'tis not so late, what needed you to have made so short a supper.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: In truth sir Cutt. we might have tickled the vanity ant, an hour longer if my watch be trustable.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: I but how should these beauties know that sir Gyles? your watch is mortal, and may err.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: That's sooth captain, but do you hear honest 〈◊〉 pray take a light, and see if the moon shine, I have a sun dial will resolve presently.

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.p: Howsoever believe it ladies, 'tis unwholesome, uncourtly, unpleasant to eat hastily, and rise suddenly, a man can show no discourse, no wit, no stirring, no variety, no pretty conceits, to make the meat go down emphatically?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Winifrid.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I prithee go to my uncle the lord Momford, and entreat him to come quicken our ears with some of his pleasant spirit; this same Fowleweather has made me so melancholy, prithee make haste.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I will madam.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: We will bid our guests good night madam, this same Foulweather makes me so sleepy.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Fie upon it, for god's sake shut the casements, here's such a fulsome air comes into this chamber; in good faith madam you must keep your house in better reparations, this same Foulweather beats in so filthily.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I'll take order with the porter for it lady, good night gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Why good night and be hanged, and you'll needs be gone.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: God give you good night madams, thank you for my good cheer, we'll tickle the vanity ant, no longer with you at this time, but I'll indite your la: to supper at my lodging one of these mornings; and that ere long too, because we are all mortal you know.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Light the lady Penelope, and the lady Hippolita to their chambers, good night fair ladies.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Good night madam, I wish you may sleep well after your light supper.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I warrant you lady I shall never be troubled with dreaming of my French suitor.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Why how now my frēchified captain Foulweather? by god's ludd thy surname is never thought upon here, I perceive here's nobody gives thee any commendations.

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.p:
Why this is the untraveled rudeness of our gross English
ladies now; would any French lady use a man thus think ye? be they any way so uncivil, and fulsome? they say they wear foul smocks, and course smocks, I say they lie, and I will die in't.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Ay, do so, pray thee, thou shalt die in a very honourable cause, thy countries general quarrel right.

sp.speaker: F●l.
sp.p: Their smocks quoth you? A my word you shall take them up so white, and so pure, so sweet, so emphatical, so moving.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: I marry sir, I think they be continually moving.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: But if their smocks were course or foul.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Nay I warrant thee thou ca rest not, so thou were: at them.

sp.speaker: Foul
sp.p: 'Sdeath they put not all their virtues in their smocks, or in their mocks, or in their stew de cocks as our ladies do.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: But in their stewed pox, there's all their gentility.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Nay good sir Cutt. do not aggravate him no more.

sp.speaker: Fowl.
sp.p: Then are they so kind, so wise, so familiar so noble, so sweet in entertainment, that when you shall, have cause to discourse or sometimes to come nearer! them; if your breath be ill, your teeth ill, or any thing about you ill why they will presently break with ye, in kind sort, good terms, pretty experiments, and tell you plain this; thus it is with your breath sir, thus it is with your teeth sir, this is your disease, and this is your medicine.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: As I am true mortal knight, it is most superlatively good, this.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Why this is courtly now, this is sweet, this plain, this is familiar, but by the court of France, our peevish dames are so proud, so precise, so coy, so disdainful, and so subtle, as the Pomonean serpent, mort dieu the punk of Babylon was never so subtle.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Nay do not chafe so captain.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Your Frenchman wood ever chase sir Cutt, being thus moved.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: What? and play with his beard so.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: I and bristle, it doth express that passion of anger very full and emphatical.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Nay good knight if your French wood bristle, let him alone, introth our ladies are a little too coy and subtle captain indeed.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Subtle sir Giles Goosecap? I assure your soul, they are as subtle with their suitors, or loves, as the Latin dialect where the nominative case, and the verb, the substantive, and the adjective, the verb, and the verb, stand as far asunder, as if they were perfect strangers one to another; and you shall hardly find them out, but then learn to construe, and pierce them, and you shall find them prepared, and acquainted, and agree together, in case, gender, and number.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I detest sir Cutt, I did not think he had been half the quintessence of a he is.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: 'Slid there's not one of them truly emphatical.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Yes I'll ensure you captain, there are many of them truly emphatical but all your French ladies are not fat? are they sir?

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Fat sir, why do ye think emphatical is fat sir Giles?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: God's my life brother knight, didst thou think so? heart I know not what it is myself, but yet I never thought it was fat, I'll be sworn to thee.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Why if any true courtly dame had had but this new fashioned suit, to entertain any thing in differently stuffed, why you should have had her more respective by far.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Nay there's some reason for that captain, methinks a true woman should perpetually dote upon a new fashion.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p:
Why you're i'th right sir Cutt. Innova fert animus mutatas dicere-formas. 'tis the mind of man, and woman
to affect new fashions; but to our mynsatives for sooth, if he come like to your besognio, or your bore, so he be rich, or emphatical, they care not; would I might never excel a Dutch skipper in courtship if I did not put distaste into my carriage of purpose; I knew I should not please them. Lackey? allume le torch.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: 'Slid, here's neither torch, nor lackey methinks .

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: O mon dew.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: O do not swear captain.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Your Frenchman ever swears sir Cutt, upon the lack of his lackey I assure you.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: See here he comes, and my lady's two pages, they have been tickling the vanity on't i'faith.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter to them Jack Bullaker, Will.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Captain Foulweather, my lady the countess Eugenia commends her most kindly to you, and is determined to morrow morning early if it be a frost to take her coach to Barnet to be nipped where if it please you, to meet her, and accompany her homeward, joining your wit with the frost, and help to nip her, she does not doubt but though you had a sad supper, you will have a joyful breakfast.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: I shall indeed my dear youth.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Why captain I abused thee, I see: I said the ladies respected thee not, and now I perceive the widow is in love with thee.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: 'Sblood knight I knew I had struck her to the quick, I wondered she departed in that extravagant fashion: I am sure I passed one passado of courtship upon her, that has heretofore made a lane amongst the French ladies like a culuering shot, I'll be sworn; and I think sir Gyles you saw how she fell under it.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O as clear as candlelight , by this daylight.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: O good knight a the post, he'll swear any thing.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: The other two ladies commend them no less kindly to you two knights too; and desire your worship's wood meet them at Barnet ith' morning with the captain.

sp.speaker: Foul. Goos. Rud.
sp.p: O. good sir.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Our worships shall attend their ladyships thither.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: No sir Giles by no means, they will go privately thither, but if you will meet them there.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Meet them, we'll die fort, but we'll meet them.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Let's go thither tonight knights, and you be true gallants.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: How greedily they take it in sirrah.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: No it is too far to go tonight , we'll be up betimes ith' morning, and not go to bed at all.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Why it's but ten miles, and a fine clear nights. Gyles

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: But ten miles? what do ye talk captain?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Why dost think its any more?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Ay, I'll ten pounds it's more than ten mile, or twelve either.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: What to Barnet?

sp.speaker: Gous.
sp.p: Ay, to Barnet?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: 'Slid, I'll lay a hundred pound with thee, if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I'll lay five hundred, to a hundred, slight I will not be out born with a wager, in that I know, I am sure it was four years agon ten miles thither, and I hope 'tis more now, 'slid do not miles grow think you, as well as other animals.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: O wise knight!

sp.speaker: Gos.
sp.p: I never innd in the town but once, and then they lodged me in a chamber so full of these ridiculus fleas, that I was fain to lie standing all night, and yet I made my man rise, and put out the candle too, because they should not see to bire me.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: A pretty project.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Intruth captain if I might advise you, you should tarry, and take the morning afore you.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: How? O mon diew, how the villain poltroon, dishonours his travail? you buffonly mushroom, are you so mere rude, and English to advise your captain?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Nay I prithee Foulweather be not tempestuous with thy poor lackey.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Tempestuous sir Cutt, will your Frenchman think you, suffer his lackey to advise him?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: O God you must take heed lackey how you advise your captain, your French lackey would not have done it.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: He would have been poxed first: allume le torch, sweet pages commend us to your ladies, say we kiss their white hands, and will not fail to meet them ▪ knights which of you leads?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Not we sir, you are a captain, and a leader.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Besides, thou art commended for the better man, for thou art very commendations itself, and captain commendations.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Why, what though I be captain commendations?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Why and captain commendations , is hearty? commendations, for captains are hearty I am sure, or else hang them,

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Why, what if I be hearty commendations, come, come, sweet knights lead the way.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: O lord sir, always after my hearty commendations.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Nay then you conquer me with precedent, by the authentical form of all justice letters. Alloun.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Here's a most sweet gudgeon swallowed, is there not?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: I but how will they digest it thinkest thou? when they shall find our ladies not there?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I have a vaunt-currying device shall make them digest it most healthfully.

lg.l: Work on sweet love, I am not yet resolved
T'exhaust this troubled spring of vanities
And nurse of perturbations, my poor life,
And therefore since in every man that holds
This being dear, there must be some desire
Whose power to enjoy his object may so mask
the judging part that in her radiant eyes
His estimation of the world may seem
Upright, and worthy, I have chosen love
To blind my reason with his misty hands
And make my estimative power believe
I have a project worthy to employ
What worth soever my whole man affords:
Then sit at rest my soul, thou now hast found
The end of thy infusion, in the eyes
Of thy divine Eugenia look for heaven.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Thanks gentle friends is your good lord and mine, gone up to bed yet?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I do assure ye not sir, not yet, nor yet, my deep, and studious friend, not yet musical Clarence.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: My lord?

sp.speaker: Mom,
sp.p: Nor yet, thou sole divider of my lordship.

lg.l: That were a most unfit division
And far above the pitch of my low plumes
I am your bold and constant guest my lord.
Far, far from bold, for thou hast known me long
Almost these twenty years, and half those years
Hast been my bedfellow; long time before
This unseen thing, this thing of naught indeed
Or atom called, my lordship shined in me,
And yet thou mak'st thy self as little bold
To take such kindness, as becomes the age
And truth of our indissoluble love
As our acquaintance sprung but yesterday
Such is thy gentle and too tender spirit.
My lord, my want of courtship makes me fear
I should be rude, and this my mean estate
Meets with such envy, and detraction
Such misconstructions, and resolved misdoomes
Of my poor worth, that should I be advanced
beyond my unseen lownesses, but one hair
I should be torn in pieces with the spirits
That fly in ill-lunged tempests through the world,
Tearing the head of virtue from her shoulders
If she but look out of the ground of glory.
Twixt, whom, and me and every worldly fortune
There fights such sour, and cursed antipathy
So waspish, and so petulant a star,
That all things tending to my grace or good
Are ravished from their object, as I were
A thing created for a wilderness
And must not think of any place with men.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: O hark you sir, this wayward mood of yours must sifted be, or rather rooted out, you'll no more music sir?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Not now my lord,

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Begun my masters then to bed, to bed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I thank you honest friends

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Hence with this book and now monsieur Clarence, methinks plain and prose friendship would do excellent well betwixt us come thus sir, or rather thus, come sir 'tis time I trow that we both lived like one body, thus, and that both our sides were slit, and concorporate with organs fit to effect an individual passage even for out very thoughts; suppose we were one body now, and I charge you believe it; where of I am the heart, and you the liver.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Your lordship might well make that division if you knew the plain song.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: O sir, and why so I pray?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: First because the heart, is the more worthy entrail, being the first that is born, and moves, and the last that moves, and dies; and then being the fountain of heat too, for wheresoever our heat does not flow directly from the heart to the other organs, there, their action must of necessity cease, and so without you I neither would nor could live.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Well sir for these reasons I may be the heart ▪ why may you be the liver now?.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I am more than ashamed, to tell you that my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Nay nay be not too suspicious of my judgement, in you I beseech you: ashamed friend? if your love overcome not that shame, a shame take that love I say. Come sir why may you be the liver?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: The plain and short truth is (My lord) because I am all liver, and turned lover.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Lover?

sp.speaker: Cla
sp.p: Lover i'faith my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Now I prithee let me leap out of my skin for joy why thou wilt not now revive the sociable mirth of thy sweet disposition? wilt thou shine in the world a new? and make those that have slighted thy love, with the austerity of thy knowledge, dote on the again with thy commanding shaft of their humours?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A 'las my lord they are all far out of my aims and only to fit myself a little better to your friendship, have I given these wilful reins to my affections.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: And i'faith is my sour friend to all worldly desires overtaken with the heart of the world? Love I shall be monstrous proud now, to hear she's every way a most rare woman that I know thy spirit, and judgement hath chosen, is she wise? is she noble? is she capable of thy virtues? will she kiss this forehead with judicial lips? where somuch judgement and virtue deserves it? Come brother twin, be short I charge you, and name me the woman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Since your lordship will shorten the length of my folly's relation, the woman that I so passionately love, is no worse lady than your own niece, the too worthy countess Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p:
Why so, so, so, you are a worthy friend are you not to conceal this love-mine in your head, and
would not open it to your heart, now beshrew my heart, if my heart dance not for joy though my heels do not, and they do not, because I will not set that at my heels that my friends set at his heart, what? friend and nephew? both nephe is a far inferior title to friend I confess, but I will prefer the backwards (As many friends do) and leave their friends worse than they found them,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But my noble lo. it is almost a prodigy, that I being only a poor gentleman and far short of that state and wealth that a lady of her greatnesses in both will expect in her husband.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p:
Hold thy doubt friend, never fear any woman, unless thyself be made of straw, or some such dry matter, and she of lightning, audacity prospers above probability in all worldly matters, dost not thou know that fortune governs them without order, and therefore reason the mother of order is none of her counsel, why should a man desiring to aspire an unreasonable creature which is a woman? seek her fruition by reasonable means, because thyself binds upon reason, wilt thou look for congruity in a woman? why? there is not one woman amongst one thousand, but will speak false Latin, and break Priscian's head, attempt nothing that you may with great reason doubt of, and out of doubt you shall obtain nothing, I tell thee friend the eminent confidence of strong spirits is the only witchcraft of this world, spirits wrestling with spirits, as bodies? with bodies? this were enough to make the hope well, if she were one of these painted communities, that are ravished with coaches, and upper hands, and brave men of dirt: but thou knowest friend she's a good scholar, and like enough to, bite at the rightest reason, and reason evermore ad optima hortetur: to like that which is best, not that which is bravest, or rightest, or greatest, and so consequently worst, but prove what she can, we will turn her, and wind her, and
make her so pliant that we will draw her through a wedding ring i'faith.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Would to god we might my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I'll warrant thee friend.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Where is mistress Winifrid; for my lady Eugenia desires to speak with your lordship.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Marry enter mistress Winifred even here I pray thee, from the lady Eugenia, do you hear friend?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Very easily on that side my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Let me feel? does not thy heart pant apace, by my heart well laboured Cupid, the field is yours sir God, and upon a very honourable composition, I am sent for now I am sure, and must even truss and to her:
Witty mistress Winifred, nay come near woman I am sure this gentleman thinks his chamber the sweeter for your dear presence.

sp.speaker: Win,
sp.p: My absence shall thank him my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: What rude mistress Winnifred? nay faith you shall come to him, and kiss him, for his kindness.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Nay good my lord, I'll never go to the market for that ware I can have it brought home to my door

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: O Winifred, a man may know by the market folks how the market goes.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: So you may my lord, but I know few lords that think scorn to go to that market themselves.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: To go to it Winifred, nay to ride to it i'faith.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: That's more than I know my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: You'll not believe it till you are then a horseback, will ye?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Come, come, I am sent of a message to you will you hear it?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Stop, stop fair Winifred, would you have audience so soon, there were no state in that i'faith; this fair gentlewoman sir.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Now we shall have a fiction I believe.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Had three suitors at once.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: You'll leave out none my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom ▪
sp.p: No more did you Winifred you interfered with them all in truth.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: O monstrous lord by this light!

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Now sir to make my tale short I will do that which she did not; vz. leave out the two first, the third coming the third night for his turn.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: My lord, my lord, my lady does that, that nobody else does, desires your company and so fare you well.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: O stay a little sweet Winifred, help me but to truss my points again, and have with you.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Not I by my truth my lord, I had rather see your hose about your heels, than I would help you to truss a point.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: O witty Winifred? for that left, take thy passport, and tell thy ladies thou leftest me with my hose about my heels.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Well, well my lord you shall sit till the moss grow a bout your he less, ere I come at you again.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: She cannot abide to hear of her three suitors; but is not this very fit my sweet Clarence? Thou seest my rare niece cannot sleep without me; but forty company's sake, she shall tonight ; and in the morning I will visit her early; when do thou but stand in that place, and thou may'st chance hear, (But art sure to see) in what subtle, and far-fetched manner I'll solicit her about thee.

sp.speaker: Cla
sp.p: Thanks worthy lord.

div.head: Saena prima

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I that have studied with world - scorning thoughts the way of heaven, and how true heaven is reached

lg.l: To know how mighty, and how many are
The strange affections of enchanted number
How to distinguish all the motions
Of the celestial bodies, and what power
Doth separate in such form this massy round:
What is his essence, efficacies, beams?
Footsteps, and shadows? what eternes●es is
The world, and time, and generation?
What soul, the world's soul is? what the black springs
And unrevealed original of things,
What their perseverance ▪ what is life and death,
And what our certain restauration?
Am with the stayed ▪ heads of this time employed
To watch withal my nerves a female shade.

div.stage: Enter Winifrid, Anabell, with their sowing works and sing: after their song enter lord Momford.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Witty mistress Winifrid, where is your countess I pray?

sp.speaker: Wyn.
sp.p: Faith your lordship is bold enough to seek her out, if she were at her urinal?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Then sh'as done it seems, for here she comes to save me that labour, away wenches, get you hence wenches.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: What, can you not abide my maid's uncle?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I never could abide a maid in my life niece, but either I draw away the maid, or the maidenhead with a wet finger.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: You love to make yourself worse then you are still.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I know few mend in this world madam, for the worse the better thought on, the better the worse spoken on ever amongst women.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I wonder where you have been all this while with your sentences.

sp.speaker: Mom,
sp.p: Faith where I must be again presently. I cannot stay long with you my dear niece.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: By my faith but you shall my lord, god's pity what will become of you shortly, that you drive maids afore you, and offer to leave widows behind you, as mankindly, as if you had taken a surfeit of our sex lately, and our very sight turned your stomach.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: God's my life, she abuses her best uncle; never trust me if it were not a good revenge to help her to the loss of her widowhood.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: That were a revenge and a half, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Nay 'twere but a whole revenge niece, but such a revenge as would more than observe the true rule of a revenge.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I know your rule before you utter it, ulcisere inimico sed sine tuo incommodo.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: O rare niece, you may see, what 'tis to be a a scholar now, learning in a woman is like weight in gold, or luster in diamonds, which in no other stone is so rich or refulgent

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But say dear uncle how could you find in your heart to stay so long from me.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Why alas niece, you're so smeared with this willful-widows three-years black weed, that I never come to you, but I dream of courses, and sepulchres, and epitaths, all the night after, and therefore adieu dear niece.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Beshrew my heart my lord, if you go these three hours.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Three hours? nay niece, if I dance attendance three hours (Alone in her chamber) with an lady so near allied to me, I am very idle i'faith, marry with such another; I would dance, one, two, three, four, and five, though it cost me ten shillings; and now I am in, have at it, my head must devise something while my feet are piddling thus, that may bring her to some fit consideration of my friend, who indeed is only a great scholar ▪ and all his honours, and riches lie in his mind. ▪

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p:
Come, come, pray tell me uncle, how does my
cousin Momford?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Why, well, very well niece, and so is my friend Clarence well too, and then is there a worthy gentleman well as any is in England I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But when did you see my cousin?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: And 'tis pity but he should do well, and he shall be well too, if all my wealth will make him well.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: What means he by this trow ye, your lo: is very dancitive methinks .

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Ay, and I could tell you a thing would make your ladyship very dancitive, or else it were very dunsative i'faith. O how the skipping of this Christmas block of ours moves the blockhead heart of a woman, and indeed any thing that pleaseth the foolish eye which presently runs with a lying tale of excellence to the mind.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But I pray tell me my lord could you tell me of a thing would make me dance say you?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Well, farewell sweet niece I must needs take my leave in earnest.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Lord bless us, here's such a stir with your farewells.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I will see you again within these two or three days a my word niece.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: God's precious, two or three days? why this lord is in a marvelous strange humour. Sit down sweet uncle, i'faith I have to talk with you about great matters.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Say then dear niece, be short utter your mind quickly now.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But I pray tell me first, what's that would make me dance i'faith?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Dance, what dance? hitherto your dancers legs bow forsooth, and caper, and jerk, and firk, and dandle the body above them, as it were their great child, though the special jerker be above this place I hope, here lies that should fetch a perfect woman over the coals i'faith.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p:
Nay good uncle say what's the thing you
could tell me of.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: No matter, no matter ▪ but let me see a passing prosperous forehead of an exceeding happy distance betwixt the eye brows; a clean lightning eye; a temperate and fresh blood in both the cheeks; excellent marks, most excellent marks of good fortune.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Why, how now uncle did you never see me before!

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Yes niece ▪ but the state of these things at this instant must be specially observed, and these outward signs being now in this clear elevation, show your untroubled mind is in an excellent power, to prefer them to act forth then a little dear niece.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: This is excellent.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: The cresses here are excellent good; the proportion of the chin good; the little aptness of it to stick out; good. And the wart above it most exceeding good. Never trust me, if all things be not answerable to the prediction of a most divine fortune towards her; vow if she have the grace to apprehend it in the nick; there's all.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Well my lord, since you will not tell me your secret, I'll keep another from you; with whose discovery, you may much pleasure me, and whose concealment may hurt my estate. And if you be no kinder than to see me so endangered; I'll be very patient of it I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Nay then it must instantly forth. This kind con juration even fires it out of me; and (To be short) gather all your judgement together, for here it comes. Niece; Clarence Clarence, rather my soul then my friend Clarence of too substantial a worth, to have any figures cast about him, (Notwithstanding, no other woman with empires could stir his affections) is with your virtues most extremely in love; and without your requital dead. And with it famed shall sound this golden distich through the world of you both.

lg.l: Non illo melior quisquam nec amantior aequi
Vir fuit, aut illa reverentior ulla dearum.
Ay me poor dame, oh you amaze me uncle,
Is this the wondrous fortune you presage?
What man may miserable women trust?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: O peace good lady, I come not to ravish you to any thing. But now I see how you accept my motion: I perceive (How upon true trial) you esteem me. Have I rid all this circuit to levy the powers of your judgement, that I might not prove their strength too suddenly with so violent a charge: and do they fight it out in white blood. And show me their hearts in the soft crystal of tears

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: O uncle you have wounded yourself in charging me that I should shun judgement as a monster, if it would not weep; I place the poor felicity of this world in a worthy friend, and to see him so unworthily revolted, I shed not the tears of my brain, but the tears of my soul. And if ever nature made tears the effects of any worthy cause, I am sure I now shed them worthily.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Her sensual powers are up i'faith, I have thrust her soul quite from her tribunal. This is her sedes vacans when her subjects are privileged to libel against her, and her friends. But weeps my kind niece for the wounds of my friendship? and I touched in friendship for wishing my friend doubled in her singular happiness?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: How am I doubled? when my honour, and good name, two essential parts of me; would be less, and lost?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: In whose judgement?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: In the judgement of the world.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p:
Which is a fool's boult. Nihil a vertute nec a viritate remotius quam vulgaris opinto: but my dear niece,
it is most true that your honour and good name tendered as they are the species of truth are worthily two essential parts of you; but as they consist only in airy titles and corruptible blood (Whose bitterness sanitas et non nobilitas efficit) and care not how many base and execrable acts they commit, they touch you no more than they touch eternity. And yet shall no nobility you have in either, be impaired neither.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Not to marry a poor gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Respect him not so; for as he is a gentleman he is noble; as he is wealthily furnished with true knowledge, he is rich and therein adorned with the exactest compliments belonging to everlasting nobleness.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Which yet will not maintain him a week: such kind of nobleness gives no coats of honour nor can scarce get a coat for necessity

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Then is it not substantial knowledge (As it is in him) but verbal and fantastical for omnia in illa ▪ ille. complexu tenet.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Why seeks he me then?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: To make you joint partners with him in all things, and there is but a little partial difference betwixt you, that hinders that universal jointure: the bigness of this circle held too near our eye keeps it from the whole sphere of the sun but; could we sustain it indifferently betwixt us and it, it would then without check of one beam appear in his fullness.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Good uncle be content for now shall I never dream of contentment.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I have more than done lady, and had rather have suffered an alteration of my being then of your judgement; but (Dear niece) for your own honour's sake repair it instantly.

See here comes the ladies; make an April day one dear love and be suddenly cheerful
God save you more than fair ladies, I am glad you're come, for my business will have me gone presently.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Why my lord Momford I say? will you go before dinner?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: No remedy sweet beauties, for which rudeness I lay my hands thus low for your pardons:

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: O courteous lord Momford!

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Niece? Mens estquae sola quietes. Sola facit claros mentemque honoribus ornat

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.p: Verus honos iuuat at mendax infamia terret.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Mine own dear nephew?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What success my lord?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Excellent; excellent; come I'll tell thee all.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Do you hear madam, how our youths here have gulled our three suitors?

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.p: Not I lady, I hope our suitors are no fit meat for our pages.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: No madam, but they are fit sauce for any man's meat I'll warrant them.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: What's the matter Hippolita?

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.p: They have sent the knights to Barnet madam this frosty morning to meet us their.

sp.speaker: E●ug..
sp.p: Is't true youths, are knights fit subjects for your knaveries ▪

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Pray pardon us madam, we would be glad to please anybody .

sp.speaker: Ja
sp.p: I indeed madam and we were sure we pleased them highly to tell them you were desirous of their company.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O 'twas good Eugenia, their livers were too hot, you know, and for temper's sake they must needs have a cooling card played upon them.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p:
And besides madam we wood have them know that your two little pages, which are less by half
then two leaves, have more learning in them then is in all their three volumes.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: i'faith will, and put their great pagical index to them too.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: But how will ye excuse your abuses wags?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: We doubt not madam, but if it please your ladyship to put up their abuses,

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Trusting they are not so dear to you, but you may.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: We shall make them gladly furnish their pockets with them.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Well, children, and fowls, agree as you will, and let the world know now, women have nothing to do with you.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Come madam I think your dinner be almost ready,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And see, here are two honourable guests for you, the lord Tales, and sir Cutberd Kingcob.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.p: Lack you any guest's madam?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I my lord such guests as you.

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.p: There's as common an answer, as yours was a question my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why? all things should be common betwixt lords, and ladies you know.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Indeed sir Kuttberd Bingcob, I have heard, you are either of the family of love, or of no religion at all.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: He may well be said to be of the family of love, he does so flow in the loves of poor overthrown ladies.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: You speak of that I wood do madam, but in earnest, I am now suing for a new mistress; look in my hand sweet lady, and tell me what fortune I shall have with her.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.p: Do you think me a witch, sir Cutberd?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Pardon me madam, but I know you to be learned in all things.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Come on let's see.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: He does you a special favour lady, to give you his open hand, for 'tis commonly shut they say.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What find you in it madam?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Shut it now and I'll tell ye.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What now lady?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You've the worst hand that ever I saw knight have ▪ when 'tis open, one can find nothing in it, and when 'tis shut one can get nothing out on't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The age of letting go is past madam, we must not now let go, but strike up men's heels, and take am as they fall.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: A good Cornish principle believe it sir Cuttberd.

sp.speaker: Tales
sp.p: But I pray tell me lady Penelope, how entertain you the love of my cousin sir Gyles Goosecap.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.p: Are the Goosecaps a kin to you my lord.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.p: Even in the first degree madam. And sir Gyles I can tell ye, though he seem something simple, is composed of as many good parts as any knight in England.

sp.speaker: Hip,
sp.p: He should be put up for concealment then, for he shows none of them.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Are you able to reckon his good parts my lord?

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.p: I'll do the best I can lady, first, he dances as comely and lightly as any man, for upon my honour, I have seen him dance upon eggs, and 'a has not broken them.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Nor cracked them neither.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.p: That I know not, indeed I wood be loath, to lie though he be my kinsman, to speak more than I know by him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Well forth my lord.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.p: He has an excellent skill in all manner of perfumes, and if you bring him gloves from forty pence, to forty shillings a pair he will tell you the price of them to two pence.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: A pretty sweet quality believe me.

sp.speaker: Tales
sp.p: Nay lady he will perfume you gloves himself; most dilicately, and give them the right Spanish titillation.
Titillation what's that my lord?

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Why lady 'tis a pretty kind of term new come up in perfuming, which they call a titillation.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Very well expounded my lord; forth with your kinsman's parts I pray.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: He is the best sempster of any woman in England, and will work you needle work edgings, and French purls from an angel to four angels a yard.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: That's precious ware indeed.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: He will work you any flower to the life, as like it as if it grew in the very place, and being a delicate perfumer, he will give it you his perfect and natural savour.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: This is wonderful; forth sweet lord tales.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: He will make you flies and worms, of all sorts most lively, and is now working a whole bed embroidered, with nothing but glow worms; whose lights a has so perfectly done, that you may go to bed in the chamber, do any thing in the chamber, without a candle.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.p: Never trust me if it be not incredible; forth my good lord.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: He is a most excellent turner, and will turn you wassel-bowles, and posset cups carved with leopard's faces, and lion's heads with spouts in their mouths, to let out the posset ale, most artificially.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Forth good lord tales.

sp.speaker: Pene.
sp.p: Nay good my lord no more, you have spoken for him thoroughly I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I lay my life Cupid has shot my sister in love with him out of your lips my lord.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Well, come in my lords, and take a bad dinner with me now, and we will all go with you at night to a better supper with the lord, and lady Furnifall.

sp.speaker: King. tale
sp.p: We attend you honourable ladies.

div.head: Scaena prima ▪

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Bullaker.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I sir.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Ride and catch the captain's horse.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: So I do sir.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: I wonder sir Gyles you wood let him go so, and not ride after him.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Wood I might never be mortal sir Cutt: if I rid not after him, till my horse sweat, so that he had ne'er a dry thread on him, and holloa'd and holloa'd to him to stay him, till I had thought my finger's ends wood have gone off with hollowings; I'll be sworn to ye and yet he ran his way like a Diogenes, and would never stay for us.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: How shall we do to get the lame captain to London, now his horse is gone?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Why he is but a lame jade neither sir Meyle, we shall soon o'ertake him I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: And yet thou sayest thou gallop'st after him as fast as thou couldst, and couldst not catch him; I lay my life some crabfish has bitten thee by the tongue, thou speakest so backward still.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: But here's all the doubt sir Cutt: if nobody should catch him now, when he comes at London, some boy or other wood get up on him and ride him hot into the water to wash him; I'll be sworn I followed one that rid my horse into the Thames, till I was up tooth knees hitherto; and if it had not been for fear of going over shoes, because I am troubled with the rheum, I wood have taught him to wash my horse when he was
Hot yfath; how now sweet captain dost feel any ease in thy pain yet ▪

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Ease in his pain quoth you, has good luck if he feel ease in pain I think, but wood any ass in the world ride down such a hill as Highgate is, in such a frost as this, and never light

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: God's precious sir cut. your Frenchman never lights I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Light sir Cutt, slight and I had my horse again, there's ne'er a paltry English frost an them all should make me light.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Go too you French zanies you, you will follow the French steps so long, till you be notable to set one sound step o'th' ground all the days of your life.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Why sir cut I care not if I be not sound so I be well but we were justly plagued, by this hill for following women thus.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: I and English women too sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Thou art still prating against English women I have seen none of the French dames I confess, but your greatest gallants for men in France, were here lately I am sure, and methinks there should be no more difference betwixt our ladies and theirs, than there is betwixt our lords and theirs, and our lords are as far beyond them i'faith, for person, and courtship, as they are beyond ours for phantasticality.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: O lord sir cut, I am sure our ladies hold our lords tack for courtship, and yet the French lords put them down, you noted it sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O God sir, I stud and heard it, as I sat ith' presence.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: How did they put them down I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Why for wit, and for courtship sir moil.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: As how good left-headed Francois.

sp.speaker: Fou ..
sp.p:
Why sir when mewsieur Lambois came to your mistress the lady Hippolita as she sat in the presence, sit down here good sir Gyles Goosecap, he kneeled me by her thus sir, and with a most quaint French art in his speech of ah bellissime, I desire to die now fares he for
in his speech of ah bellissime I desire to die now says he for your love that I might be buried here.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: A good pickt-hatched compliment by my faith; but I prithee what answered she.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: She, I scorn to note that I hope then did he vie it again with another hah.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: That was hah, hah, I wood have put the third hah to it, if I had been as my mistress, and ha-ha-ha'ed him out of the presence i'faith,

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Ha says he, these fair eyes, I wood not for a million they were in France, they wood renew all our civil-wars again.

sp.speaker: Goose.
sp.p: That was not so good methinks captain.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Well-judged i'faith, there was a little wit in that I must confess, but she put him down far, and answered him with a question and that was whether he wood seem a lover or a jester , if a lover a must tell her far more likelier than those, or else she was far from believing them, if a jester, she could have much more ridiculous jests than his of twenty fools that followed the court, and told him she had as lief be courted with a brush faggot as with a Frenchman, that spent itself all in sparks, and would sooner fire ones chimney then warm the house, and that such sparks were good enough yet to set thatched dispositions a fire, but hers was tilled with sleight, and respected them as slightly.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Why so captain, and yet you talk of your great Frenchmen, to God little England had never known them I may say.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: What's the matter sir Giles, are you out of love with Frenchmen now of a sudden.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p:
'Slid captain wood not make one, I'll be sworn, I'll be sworn, they took away a masty dog of mine by commission now, I think on't makes my tears stand in my eyes with grief, I had rather lost the dearest friend that ever I lay withal, in my life be this light, never stir if
if he fought not with great Sekerson four hours to one, foremost take up hindmost, and took so many loaves from him, that he starved him presently: so at last the dog could do no more than a bear could do, and the bear being heavy with hunger you know, fell upon the dog, broke his back, and the dog never stirred more.

sp.speaker: Rud
sp.p: Why thou sayest the Frenchmen took him away.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Frenchmen, ay, so they did too, but yet and he had not been killed, 'twould ne'er a grieved me.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: O excellent unity of speech.

div.stage: Enter Will and Jack at several doors.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Save ye knights.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Save you captain.

sp.speaker: Faul.
sp.p: Pages, welcome my fine pages.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Welcome boys.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Welcome sweet will, good Jack.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: But how chance you are so far from London now pages, is it not almost dinner time.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Yes indeed sir, but we left our fellows to wait for once, and could not choose in pure love to your worships, but we must needs come and meet you, before you met our ladies, to tell you a secret.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: A secret, what secret I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: If ever your worships say any thing ▪ we are undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Not for a world believe it.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Why then this it is; we overheard our ladies as they were talking in private say they refused to meet you at Barnet this morning of purpose, because they wood try which of you were most patient.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: And some said you, sir Gyles, another you sir and the third you captain,

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: This was excellent.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p:
Then did they swear one another not to excuse themselves to you by any means, that they might try you the better, now if they shall see you say nothing in the
world to them, what may come of it, when ladies begin to try their suitors once, I hope your wisdoms can judge a little.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: O ho my little knave let us alone now i'faith, wood I might be cashiered, if I say any thing.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Faith and I can forbear my tongue as well as another I hope.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Wood I might be degraded if I speak a word, I'll tell them I care not for losing my labour.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Come knights shall we not reward the pages?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Yes I prithee do, sir Gyles give the boys something.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Never stir sir Cutt, if I have ever a groat about me but one three pence.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Well knights I'll lay out for's all, here my fine pages.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: No in deed an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: O pages refuse a gentleman's bounty.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Cry you mercy sir, thank you sweet captain

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: And what other news is stirring my fine villiacos.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Marry sir they are invited to a great supper tonight to your lords house captain ▪ the lord Furnifall, and there will be your great cousin sir Gyles Goosecap, the lord Tales, and your uncle sir Cutt. Rudesby, sir Cutbert Kingcob.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: The lord Tales, what countryman is he?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: A Kentish lord sir, his ancestors came forth off Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Out of Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: I indeed sir the best tales in England are your Canterbury tales, I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: The boy tells thee true captain.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
He writes his name sir, tales, and he being the tenth son his father had; his father christed him decem tales, and so his whole name is the
lord decem Tales.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: A my mortality the boy knows more than I do of our house.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: But is the lady Furnifall (Captain) still of the same drinking humour she was wont to be.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Still of the same knight, and is never in any sociable vain till she be tipsy, for in her sobriety she is mad, and fears my good little old lord out of all proportion.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: And therefore as I hear he will earnestly invite guests to his house, of purpose to make his wife drunk, and then dotes on her humour most profanely.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: 'Tis very true knight; we will sup with them tonight ; and you shall see her; and now I think on't, I'll tell you a thing knights, wherein perhaps you may exceedingly pleasure me.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: What's that good captain.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: I am desirous to help my lord to a good merry fool, and if I could help him to a good merry one, he might do me very much credit I assure ye.

sp.speaker: R●d.
sp.p: 'Sblood thou speakest to us as if we could serve thy turn.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: O France sir Cutt: your Frenchman wood not have taken me so, for a world, but because fools come into your companies many times to make you merry

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: As thou dost.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Nay good sir Cutt: you know fools do come into your companies.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: I and thou knowest it too, no man better.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Bear with choler sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: But wood you help your lord to a good fool so fain sir.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: I my good page exceeding fain.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: You mean a wench, do you not sir, a foolish wench?

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Nay I wood have a man fool, for his lord: page ▪

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Does his lord: love a fool, so well I pray.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p:
Assure thyself page, my lord loves a fool as
he loves himself.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Of what degree wood you have your fool sir, for you may have of all manner of degrees.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Faith I wood have him a good emphatical fool, one that wood make my lord laugh well, and I cared not,

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Laugh well (Umh) than we must know this sir, is your lord costive of laughter, or laxative of laughter?

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Nay he is good merry little lord, and indeed something laxative of laughter.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why then sir the less wit will serve his lordship's turn, marry if he had been costive of laughter, he must have had two or three drams of wit the more in his fool, for we must ●inister according to the quantity of his lord: humour you know, and if he should have as much wit in his fool being laxative of laughter, as if he were costive of laughter, why he might laugh himself into an epilepsy, and fall down dead suddenly, as many have done with the extremity of that passion; and I know your lord cares for nothing, but the health of a fool.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Thou'rt ith' right my notable good page.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Why, and for that health sir we will warrant his lordship, that if he should have all Bacon de sanitate tuenda read to him, it should not please his lordship so well as our fool shall.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Remercy my more than English pages.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: A my word I have not seen pages have so much wit, that have never been in France captain.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed sir Gyles, well then my almost French elixers ▪ will you help my lord to a fool, so fit for him as you say.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: As fit, I'll warrant you captain, as if he were made for him, and he shall come this night to supper, and fool where his lord: sits at table.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Excellent sir, fail not now my sweet pages.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Not for a world sir, we will go both, and seek him presently.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Do so my good wags

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Save you knights.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Save you captain.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Farewell my pretty knaves, come knights, shall we resolve to go to this supper?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: What else.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: And let's provide torches for our men to sit at door with all captain.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: That we will I warrant you sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Torches? why the moon will shine man.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: The moon sir cut: I scorn the moon i'faith, 'slid sometimes a man shall not get her to shine and if he wood give her a couple of capons, and one of them must be white too, God forgive me I cud never abide her since yesterday, she served me such a trick tother night.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: What trick sir Gyles?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Why sir cut: cause the days be mortal and short now you know, and I love day light well; I thought it went a way faster than it needed, and run after it into Finsburie-fieldes ith' calm evening to see the wind mills go? And even as I was going over a ditch the moon by this light of purpose runs me behind a cloud, and lets me fall into the ditch by heaven.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: That was ill done in her in deed sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Ill done sir cut: 'slid a man may bear, and bear, but and she have no more good manners, but to make every black slovenly cloud a pearl in her eye I shall ne'er love English moon again, while I live I'll be sworn to ye.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Come knights to London horse, horse, horse.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p:
In what a case he is with the poor English moon, because the French moons (Their torches) will be
the less in fashion, and I warrant you the captain will remember it too, though he say no thing, he seconds his resolute chaseso and follows him, I'll lay my life you shall see them the next cold night, shut the moonshine out of their chambers, and make it lie without doors all night. I discredit my wit with their companies now I think on't, plague a god on them; I'll fall a beating on them presently.

div.stage: Enter lord Momford and Clarence. Clarence Horatio.

lg.l: Sing good Horatio, while I sigh and write.
According to my master Plato's mind
The soul is music, and doth therefore joy
In accents musical, which he that hates
With points of discord is together tied
And barks at reason, consonant in sense.
Divine Eugenia, bears the ●ular form
Of music and of reason, and presents
The soul exempt from flesh in flesh inflamed,
Who must not love her then, that loves his soul?
To her I write, my friend, the star of friends
Will needs have my strange lines greet her strange eyes
And for his sake I'll pour my poor soul forth
In floods of ink; but did not his kind hand
Bar me with violent grace, I wood consume.
In the white flames of her impassionate love
Ere my harsh lips should vent the odorous blaze.
For I am desperate of all worldly joys
And there was never man so harsh to men,
When I am fullest of digested life
I seem a liveless embryon to all
Each day racked up in nightlike funeral.
Sing good Horatio, whilst I sigh and write.

body.head: The letter.
body.p: Suffer him to love that suffers not loving, my love is without passion and therefore free from alteration.

lg.l: Prose is too harsh, and verse is poetry
Why should I write then? merit clad in ink
Is but a mourner, and as good as naked
I will not write my friend shall speak for me
Sing one stave more my good Horatio.
I must remember I know whom I love,
A dame of learning, and of life exempt
From all the idle fancies of her sex,
And this that to another dame wood seem
Perplexed and folded in a rudelesse veil
Will be more clear than ballads to her eye
I'll write, if but to satisfy my friend.
Your third stance sweet Horatio and no more.
How vainly do I offer my strange love?
I marry, and bid states, and entertain
Ladies with tales and jests, and lords with news
And keep a house to feast Actaeon's hounds
That eat their master, and let idle guests
Draw me from serious search of things divine
To bid them sit, and welcome, and take care
To soothe their palates with choice kitchenstuff
As all must do that marry and keep house
And then look on the left side of my yoke
Or on the right perhaps and see my wife
Draw in a quite repugnant course from me
Busied to starch her French purls, and her puffs
When I am in my anima refiexa quid sit faelicitas quae origo rerum?
And make these beings that are known to be
The only serious objects of true men
Seem shadows, with substantial stir she keeps
About her shadows, which if husband's love
they must believe, and thus my other self
Brings me another body to dispose
That have already much too much of one,
And must not look for any soul of her
To help two rule to bodies.
Fie for shame.
I never heard of such an antedame.
Do women bring no help of soul to men?
Why friend they either are men's souls themselves
Or the most witty imitatrixes of them
Or prettiest sweet apes of human souls,
That ever nature framed; as I will prove.
For first they be substantiae lucidae
And purer than men's bodies like their souls,
Which men's harsh hairs both of their breast and chin
Occasioned by their gross and ruder heat
Plainly demonstrates: then like souls they do,
Movere corpora, for no power on earth
Moves a man's body, as a woman does!
Then do they dare formas corpori
Or add fair forms to men, as their souls do:
For but for women, who wood care for forms?
I vow I never wood wash face, nor hands
Nor care how ragged, or slovenly I went
Were't not for women, who of all men's pomps
Are the true final causes: then they make
Men in their seeds immortal like their souls
That else wood perish in a span of time.
O they be soulelike-creatures, and my niece
The soul of twenty rare souls styled in one.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: That, that it is my lord, that makes me love.

lg.l: O are ye come sir, welcome to my niece
As I may say at midnight gentle friend
What have you wrote I pray?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Strange stuff my lord. he reads and comments.

lg.l: Indeed the way to believe is to love
And the right way to love is to believe,
this I will carry now with pen and ink
For her to use in answer, see, sweet friend
She shall not stay to call, but while the steel
Of her affection is made soft and hot,
I'll strike and take occasion by the brow.
Blessed is the wooing that's not long a doing.
Had ever man so true, and noble friend?
Or wood men think this sharp world's freezing air
To all true honour and judicial love
Wood suffer such a florishing pine in both
To overlook the boxe-trees of this time?
When the learnd mind hath by impulsion wrought
Her eyes clear fire into a knowing flame.
No elemental smoke can darken it
Nor Northern coldness nip her Daphnean flower,
Oh sacred friendship thanks to thy kind power
That being retired from all the faithless world
Appear'st to me in my unworldly friend,
And for thine own sake let his noble mind
By moving precedent to all his kind
(Like just Deucalion) of earth's stony bones
Repair the world with humane blood and flesh
And dying virtue with new life refresh.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter tales, Kingcob, Eugenia, Hippolita, Penelope, Winnifred.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: 'Tis time to leave your chests ladies 'tis too studious an exercise after dinner.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Why is it called chests?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Because they lean upon their chests that play at it.

sp.speaker: Tal
sp.p: I wood have it called the strife of wits, for 'tis a game so witty, that with strife for mastery, we hunt it eagerly.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.p: Specially where the wit of the Goosecaps are in chase my lord.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: I am a Goosecap by the mother's side madam, at least my mother was a Goosecap.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: And you were her white son, I warrant my lord.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: I was the youngest lady, and therefore must be her white son ye know, the youngest of ten I was.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And the wisest of fifteen.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: And sweet lady will ye cast a kind eye now upon my cousin, sir Gyles Goosecap.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Pardon my lord I have never a spare eye to cast away I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: I wonder you should count it cast away lady upon him, do you remember those few of his good parts I rehearsed to you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Very perfectly my lord, amongst which one of them was, that he is the best sempster of any woman in England, pray let's see some of his work?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Sweet lord let's see him sow a little.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: You shall a mine honour lady.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: He's a goodly great knight indeed; and a little needle in his hand will become him prettily.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: From the Spanish pike to the Spanish needle, he shall play with any knight in England lady.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But not ● converso, from the Spanish needle to the Spanish pike.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I think he be too wise for that indeed madam, for he has 20. miles length in land lies together, and he wood be loath to bring it all to the length of a pike.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: But no man commends my blunt servant sir Cutt: Rudeshy methinks.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
He is a kind gentleman lady though he be blunt, and is of this humour, the more you presume upon him without ceremony, the more
he loves you, if he know you think him kind once and will say nothing but still use him, you may melt him into any kindness you will; he is right like a woman, and had rather, you should bluntly take the greatest favour you can of him, then shamefastly entreat it.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.p: He says well to you Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.p: I madam, but they 〈◊〉, he will beat one in jest, and bite in kindness, and tear ones ruffs in courtship.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Some that he makes sport withal perhaps, but none that he respects I ye assure.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And what's his living sir Cutbeard?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Some two thousand a year lady.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I pray do not tell him that I asked, for I stand not upon living.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: O good lady who can live without living?

sp.speaker: Mom
sp.p: Still here lordings? good companions i'faith, I see you come not for victuals.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Victuals, my lord, I hope we have victuals at home.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I but sweet lord, there is a principle in the politicians physic, that not your meat upon other men's trenchers, and beware of surfeits of your own cost many good companions cannot abide to eat meat at home ye know. And how fares my noble niece now, and her fair lady Feeres?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: What wind blows you hither trow?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Hark you madam, the sweet gale of one Clarence's breath, with this his paper sail blows me hither.

sp.speaker: E●g.
sp.p: Ay me still, in that humour? beshrew my heart it I take any papers from him.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Kind bosom do thou take it then.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Nay then never trust me.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Let it fall then, or cast it away you were best, that everybody may discover your love suits, do; there's somebody near if you note it, and how have you spent the time since dinner nobles?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: At chests my lords,

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Read it niece.

sp.speaker: E●g.
sp.p: Here bear it back I pray.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I bear you on my back to hear you; and how play the lady's sir Cuthbert, what men do they play best withal, with knights or rooks?

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: With knights my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: 'Tis pity their board is no broader, and that some men called gulls are not added to their game

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why my lo it needs not, they make the knights gulls.

sp.speaker: Mom
sp.p: That's pretty sir Cuthbert; you have begun I know niece, forth I command you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: O you're a sweet uncle.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I have brought her a little Greek, to help me out withal, and she's so coy of her learning for sooth she makes it strange: lords, and ladies, I invite you all to supper tonight , and you shall not deny me.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: We will attend your lordship.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Come ladies let's into the gallery a little.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: And now what says mine own dear niece i'faith?

sp.speaker: E●g.
sp.p: What should she say to the backside of a paper.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Come, come, I know you have been a'the belly side.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Now was there ever lord so prodigal, of his own honoured blood, and dignity?

sp.speaker: Mom
sp.p: Away with these same horse fair alligations, will you answer the letter?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p:
God's my life you go like a cunning spokes man,
man, answer uncle? what do ye think me desperate of a husband

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Not so niece, but careless of your poor uncle.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I will not write that's certain.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: What will you have my friend and I perish, do you thirst our bloods?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: O you're in a mighty danger no doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: If you have our bloods beware our ghosts I can tell ye, come will ye write?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I will not write i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I'faith dame, than I must be your secretary I see, here's the letter, come, do you dictate and I'll write.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: If you write no otherwise than I dictate, it will scarce prove a kind answer I believe.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: But you will be advised I trust. Secretaries are of counsel with their countesses, thus it begins. Suffer him to love, that suffers not loving, what answer you to that?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: He loves extremely that suffers not in love.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: He answers you for that presently, his love is without passion, and therefore free from alteration, for Pa● you know is in alterationem labi he loves you in his soul he tells you, wherein there is no passion, say dame what answer you.
