sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Nay if I answer any thing.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Why? very well, I'll answer for you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You answer? shall I set my hand to your answer?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I by my faith shall ye.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: By my faith, but you shall answer as I wood have you then.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Always put in with advice of your secretary, niece, come, what answer you?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Since you needs will have my answer, I'll answer briefely to the first, and last part of his letter.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Do so niece, and leave the midst for himself a god's name, what is your answer?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I cannot but suffer you to love, if you do love.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Why very good, there it is, and will requite your love; say you so? he writes and she dictates.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Beshrew my lips then my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Beshrew my fingers but you shall; what, you may promise to requite his love, and yet not promise him marriage I hope; well, and will requite your love.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Nay good my lord hold your hand, for I'll be sworn, I'll not set my hand to't.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Well hold of your hand good madam till it should come on, I'll be ready for it anon, I warrant ye now forth; my love is without passion, and therefore free from alteration, what answer you to that madam?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Even this my lord, your love being mental, needs no bodily requital.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I am content with that, and here it is; but in heart.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: What but in heart?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Hold of your hand yet I say, I do embrace and repay it,

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You may write uncle, but if you get my hand to it,

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Alas niece this is nothing, is't any thing to a bodily marriage, to say you love a man in soul if your hearts agree and your bodies meet not? simple marriage rites, now let us forth: he is in the way to felicity, and desires your hand.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: My hand shall always sign the way to felicity.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Very good, may not any woman say this now. Conclude now sweet niece.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And so God prosper your journey.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p:
Charitably concluded, though far short of that love I wood have shown to any friend of yours
niece I swear to you, your hand now, and let this little stay his appetite.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Read what you have writ my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: What needs that madam, you remember it I am sure.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Well if it want sense in the composition, let my secretary be blamed for't, theirs my hand.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Thanks gentle niece, now I'll read it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Why now, more than before I pray?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: That you shall see straight, I cannot but suffer you to love if you do love and will requite your love.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Remember that requital was of your own putning it, but it shall be after my fashion I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Interrupt me no more, your love being mental needs no bodily requital, but in heart I embrace and repay it; my hand shall always sign the way to felicity, and myself knit with you in the bands of marriage ever walk with you, in it, and so God prosper our journey:

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: God's me life, 'tis not thus I hope.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: By my life but it is niece.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: By my life but 'tis none of my deed then.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Do you use to set your hand to that which is not your deed, your hand is at it niece, and if there be any law in England, you shall perform it too:

lg.l: Why, this is plain dishonoured deceit.
Does all your truest kindness end in law?
Have patience niece, for whatsoe'er I say
Only the laws of faith, and thy free love
Shall join my friend and thee, or naught at all,
By my friend's love, and by this kiss it shall.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Why, thus did false Accontius snare Cydippe.

lg.l: Indeed dear love his wile was something like
And then 'tis no unheard-of
That was enacted in a god's eye,
Accontius worthy love feared not Diana
before whom he contrived this sweet deceit

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Well there you have my hand, but I'll be sworn I never did thing so against my will.

lg.l: 'Twill prove the better madam, doubt it not ▪
And to allay the billows of your blood,
Raised with my motion bold and opposite
Dear niece sup with me, and refresh your spirits:
I have invited your companions
With the two guests that dined with you to day,
And will send for the old lord Love-all
The captain, and his mates and (Though at night)
We will be merry as the morning lark.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: No, no my lord, you will have Clarence there.

lg.l: A 'las poor gentleman I must tell you now
He's extreme sick, and was so when he writ
Though he did charge me not to tell you so;
And for the world he cannot come abroad.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Is this the man that without passion loves

lg.l: I do not tell you he is sick with love;
Or if he be 'tis wilful passion.
Which he doth choose to suffer for your sake
And could restrain his sufferance with a thought,
Upon my life he will not trouble you;
And therefore worthy niece fail not to come.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I will on that condition.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: 'Tis performed: for were my friend well and could comfort me; I wood not now entreat your company, but one of you I must have, or I die, o such a friend is worth a monarchy.

div.stage: Enter lord Furnifall. Rudesby. Goosecap. Fowlweather. Bullaker.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay my gallants I will tell you more.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Forth good my lord.

lg.l: The evening came and then our waxen stars
Sparkled about the heavenly court of France.
When I then young and radiant as the sun
give luster to those lamps, and curling thus
My golden foretop ▪ stepped into the presence,
Where set with other princely dames I found
The countess of Lancalier and her niece
Who as I told you cast so fixed an eye
On my behaviours talking with the King:

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: True my good lord.

lg.l: They rose when I came in, and all the lights
Burned dim for shame, when I stood up and shined.

sp.speaker: Foul
sp.p: O most passionate description sir Cutt:

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: True of a candle's end.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: The passingst description of a candle, that ever lived sir Cutt:

lg.l: Yet aimed I not at them, nor seemed to note
What grace they did me, but found courtly cause
To talk with an accomplished gentleman
New come from Italy, in quest of news ▪
I spoke italian with him.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: What so young?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: O rarissime volte cadono nel parlar nostro familiar.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: 'Slid 'a could speak it knight, at three year old.

lg.l: Nay gentle captain do not set me forth
I love it not, in truth I love it not.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: 'Slight my lord but truth is truth you know.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I dare ensure your lordship, truth is truth, and I have heard in France, they speak French as well, as their mother tongue my lord.

lg.l: Why 'tis their mother tongue my noble knight ▪
But (As I tell you) I seemed not to note
The lady's notes of me, but held my talk,
With that italianate Frenchman, and took time
(Still as our conference served) to show my courtship
In the three quarter leg, and settled look,
The quick kiss of the top of the forefinger
And other such exploits of good accost;
All which the ladies took into their eyes
With such attention that their favours swarmed
about my bosom, in my hat, mine ears,
In scarves about my thighs, upon mine arms
Thick on my wrists, and thicker on my hands,
And still the less I sought, the more I found.
All this I tell to this notorious end,
That you may use your courtship with less care
To your coy mistresses; as when we strike
A goodly salmon, with a little line
We do not tug to hale her up by force
For then our line wood break, and our hook lost;
But let her careless play alongst the stream
As you had left her, and she'll drown her self.

sp.speaker: Foul
sp.p: A my life a most rich comparison.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Never stir, if it be not a richer caparison, than my lord my cousin wore at tilt, for that was broidered with nothing but moonshine ith' the water, and this has Salmons in't; by heaven a most edible caparison.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Odious thou wouldst say, for comparisons are odious.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: So they are indeed sir Cutt ▪ all but my ▪ lords.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Be caparisons odious sir Cutt: what like flowers?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: O ass they be odorous.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: A botts a' that stinking word odorous, I can never hit on't,

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: And how like you my court-counsel gallants ha ▪

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Out of all proportion excellent my lord: and believe it for emphatical courtship, your lordship puts down all the lords of the court.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No good captain no.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: By France you do my lord for emphatical courtship.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: For emphatical courtship indeed I can do somewhat.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Then does your merry entertainment become you so festivally, that you have all the bravery of a saint George's day about ye when you use it.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay that's too much in sadness captain.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p:
O good my lord, let him praise you, whatsoe'er
it costs your lordship.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: I assure your lordship your merry behaviour does so festivally show upon you, that every high holiday when ladies wood be most beautiful; every one wishes to God she were turned into such a little lord as you, when you're merry.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: By this fire they do my lord, I have heard am.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Marry God forbid knight they should be turned into me; I had rather be turned into them a' mine honour.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Then for your lordship's quips, and quick jests, why gesta romanorum were nothing to them a my virtue

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Well, well, well, I will hear thee no more, I will hear thee no more, good captain, thou'st an excellent wit, and thou shalt have crowns a' mine honour, and now knights and captain, the fool you told me off, do you all know him?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I know him best my lord.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Do you sir Gyles, to him then good knight, and be here with him, and here, and here, and here again; I mean paint him unto us sir Gyles, paint him lively, lively now, my good knightly boy.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Why my good lord? he will ne'er be long from us, because we are all mortal you know.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Very true,

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: And as soon as ever we go to dinner, and supper together,

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Dinner and supper together, whence that trow?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: 'A will come you in amongst us, with his cloak buttoned, loose under his chin.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Buttoned loose my lord?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I me lord buttoned loose still, and both the flaps cast o'er before, both his shoulders afore him.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Both shoulders afore him?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: From before him he means; forth good sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Like a potentate my lord?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Much like a potentate indeed.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: For all the world like a potentate S. cut: ye know.

sp.speaker: Rud,
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: All his beard nothing but hair.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Or something else.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Or something else as you say.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Excellent good.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: His melons, or his apricots, oranges always in an unclean hand kerchief very cleanly I warrant you my lord.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: A good neat fool sir Gyles of mine honour.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Then his fine words that he sets them in, concaticall, a fine aniseed wench fool upon ticket and so forth.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Passing strange words believe me,

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Know'th every man at the table, though he never saw him before, by sight and then will he fool you so finely my lord, that he will make your heart ache, till your eyes run over.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: The best that ever I heard, grey mercy good knight for thy merry description, captain, I give thee twenty companies of commendations, never to be cashiered.

div.stage: Enter Jack and Will on the other side.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Save your lordship,

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: My pretty cast of Merlin's, what prophecies with your little masterships?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Things that cannot come to pass my lord, the worse our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Why what's the matter pages?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: How now my lady's foisting hounds.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: M. Jack ▪ m. Jack; how do ye m. William, frolic?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Not so frolic, as you left us sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why wags, what news bring you a god's name.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Heavy news indeed my lord, pray pardon us.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Heavy news? not possible your little bodies could bring am then, unload those your heavy news I beseech ye?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why my lord the fool we took for your lord: is thought too wise for you, and we dare not present him,

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: 'Slid pages, you'll not cheats of our fool will ye?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Why sir Giles, he's too dogged and bitter for you in truth, we shall bring you a fool to make you laugh, and he shall make all the world laugh at us.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I indeed sir Giles, and he knows you so well too

sp.speaker: Giles
sp.p: Know me ▪ slight he knows me no more than the begger knows his dish.

sp.speaker: Ja
sp.p: Faith he begs you to be content sir Giles, for he will not come.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Beg me? slight I wood I had known that, tother day, I thought I had met him in Paul's, and he had been anybody else but a pillar, I wood have run him through by heaven, beg me?

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: He begs you to be content sir Giles, that is, he prays you ▪

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O does he praise me, than I commend him.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Let this unsuitable fool go sir Giles, we will make shift without him.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: That we will a my word my lord, and have him too for all this.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Do not you say so sir Giles, for to tell you true that fool is dead.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Dead? 'slight that cannot be man, I know he wood ha' writ to me on't had been so.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Quick or dead let him go sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I my lord, for we have better news for you to hearken after.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What are they my good novations?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: My lord Momford entreats your lordship and these knights and captain to accompany the countess Eugenia and the other two ladies at his house at supper tonight .

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: All desiring your lo: to pardon them, for not eating your meat tonight .

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Withal my heart wags, and theirs amends; my hearts, now set your courtship a'the last, a'the tainters, and prick up yourselves for the ladies.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O brave sir Cut come let's prick up the ladies:

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: And will not the knights two noble kinsmen be there?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Both will be their my lord.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why there's the whole knot of us then, and there shall we knock up the whole triplicity of your nuptials.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I'll make my lord my cousin speak for me.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: And your lordship will be for me I hope.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: With tooth and nail captain, a my lord.

sp.speaker: Rua.
sp.p: Hang am tytts I'll pommel myself into am.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Your lo: your cousin sir Gyles has promised the ladies they shall see you sow.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: God's me, wood I might never be mortal if I do not carry my work with me.

lg.l: Do so sir Gyles, and withal use means
To taint their high bloods with the shaft of love,
Sometimes a finger's motion wounds their minds;
A jest, a gesture, or a pretty laugh.
A voice, a present, ah, things done ith' nick
Wound deep, and sure, and let fly your gold
And we shall nuptials have hold belly hold.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O rare sir Cutt: we shall eat nutshells. hold belly hold

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: O pitiful knight, that knows not nuptials from nutshells.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And now comme porte vous monsieur?

sp.speaker: Bull
sp.p: Portae bien vous remercy.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: We may see it indeed sir, and you shall go afore with us.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: No good monsieurs.

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.p: Another crash in my lady's cellar i'faith monsieur.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Remercy de bon ceur monsieurs.

lg.l: How now my friend does not the knowing beams
That through thy common sense glance through thy eyes
To read that letter, through thine eyes retire
And warm thy heart with a triumphant fire?
My lord I feel a treble happiness
Mix in one soul, which proves how eminent
Things endless are above things temporal,
That are in bodies needfully confined;
I cannot suffer their dementions pierced
Where my immortal part admits expansure
Even to the comprehension of two more
Commixed substantially with her mere self.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: As how my strange, and riddle ▪ speaking friend?

lg.l: As thus my lord, I feel my own minds joy
As it is separate from all other powers,
And then the mixture of another soul
Joined in direction to one end, like it,
And thirdly the contentment I enjoy,
As we are joined that I shall work that good
In such a noble spirit as your niece,
Which in myself I feel for absolute;
Each good mind doubles his own free content
When in another's use they give it vent.
Said like my friend, and that I may not wrong
Thy full perfections with an emptier grace,
Then that which show presents to thy conceits,
In working thee a wife worse than she seems;
I'll tell thee plain a secret which I know.
My niece doth use to paint herself with white
Whose cheeks are naturally mixed with red
Either because she thinks pale-looks moves most:
Or of an answerable nice affect
To other of her modest qualities;
Because she wood not with the outward blaze
Of tempting beauty tangle wanton eyes;
And so be troubled with their tromperies:
which construe as thou wilt. I make it known
That thy free comment may examine it,
As willinger to tell truth of my niece,
Then in the least degree to wrong my friend.
A jealous part of friendship you unfold;
For was it ever seen that any dame
Wood change of choice a well mixed white and red
For bloodless paleness, if she strived to move?
Her painting then is to shun motion,
But if she mended some defect with it
Breeds it more hate than other ornaments;
(Which to supply bare nature) ladies wear?
What an absurd thing is it to suppose;
(If nature made us either lame or sick,)
We wood not seek for sound limbs, or for health
By art the rector of confused nature?
So in a face if nature be made lamer
Than art can make it, is it more offence
To help her want there then in other limbs?
Who can give instance where dames faces lost
The privilege their other parts may boast.
But our most court received poets says
That painting is pure chastity's abator.
That was to make up a poor rhyme to nature.
And far from any judgement it conferred
For lightness comes from hearts, and not from looks
And if inchastity possess the heart;
Not painting doth not raze it, nor being clear
Doth painting spot it,
Omne bonum naturaliter pulchrum.
For outward fairness bears the divine form,
And moves beholders to the act of love;
And that which moves to love is to be wished
And each thing simply to be wished is good.
So I conclude mere painting of the face
A lawful and a commendable grace ▪
What paradox dost thou defend in this
and yet through thy clear arguments I see
Thy speech is far exempt from flattery,
And how illiterate custom grossly errs?
Almost in all traditions she prefers.
Since then the doubt I put thee of my niece,
Cheques not thy doubtless love, forth my dear friend,
And to all force to those impressions,
That now have carved her fantasy with love,
I have invited her to supper here.
And told her thou art most extremely sick.
Which thou shalt counterfeit with all thy skill,

sp.speaker: Cla:
sp.p: Which is exceeding small to counterfeit,

lg.l: Practice a little, love will teach it thee,
And then shall doctor Versey the physician,
Come to thee while herself is in my house.
With whom as thou conferest of thy disease,
I'll bring my niece with all the lords and ladies.
Within your hearing under feigned pretext,
To show the pictures that hang near thy chamber,
Where when thou hearst my voice, know she is there.
And therefore speak that which may stir her thoughts,
And make her fly into thy opened arms.
Ladies whom true worth cannot move to ruth
True lovers must deceive to show their truth

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Momford, Furnifall, Tales, Kingcob, Rudesbie, Goosecap, Foulweather, Eugenia, Hippolita, Penelope, Winnifred.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Where is sir Gyles Goosecap here?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Here my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Come forward knight 'tis you that the ladies admire at working a mine honour.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: A little at once my lord for idleness' sake.

sp.speaker: Fur:
sp.p: Sir cut, I say, to her captain.

sp.speaker: Penel:
sp.p: Come good servant let's see what you work.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: Why look you mistress ▪ I am making a fine dry sea, full of fish, playing in the bottom, and here I'll let in the water so lively, that you shall hear it roar.

sp.speaker: Eug:
sp.p: Not hear it sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Yes in sooth madam with your eyes.

sp.speaker: Tal:
sp.p: I lady; for when a thing is done so exceedingly to the life, as my knightly cousin does it, the eye oftentimes takes so strong a heed of it, that it cannot contain it alone, and therefore the ear seems to take part with it.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: That's a very good reason my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: What a jest it is, to hear how seriously he strives to make his foolish kinsman's answers wise ones.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: What shall this be servant?

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: This shall be a great whale mistress, at all his bigness spouting huge hills of salt-water afore him, like a little ▪ water squirt, but you shall not need to fear him mistress, for he shall be si●ke and gold ▪ he shall do you no harm, and he be ne'er so lively.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Thank you good servant.

sp.speaker: Tal:
sp.p: Do not think lady, but he had need tell you this a forehand for a mine honour, he wrought me the monster Caucasus so lively, that at the first sight I started at it.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: The monster Caucasus my lord? Caucasus is a mountain; Cacus you mean.

sp.speaker: Tal:
sp.p: Cacus indeed my lord, cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: Here I'll take out your eye, and you will mistress.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: No by my faith servant 'tis better in

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Why lady, I'll but take it out in jest, in earnest.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: No, something else there, good servant.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Why then here shall be a camel, and he shall have horns, and he shall look (For all the world) like a maid without a husband.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O bitter sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Nay he has a dry wit lady I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: He bobbed me there indeed my lord.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Marry him sweet lady, to answer his bitter bob.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: So she may answer him with horns indeed.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: See what a pretty work he wears in his boot ▪ hose.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Did you work them yourself sir Gyles, or buy them?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I bought am for nothing madam in th'exchange

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Bought am for nothing.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Indeed madam in th'exchange they so honour him for his work that they will take nothing for any thing he buys on am; but where's the rich nightcap you wrought cousin ▪ if it had not been too little for you, it was the best piece of work, that ever I saw.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Why my lord, was big enough, when I wrought it, for I wore pantables than you know.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Indeed the warmer a man keeps his feet the less he needs wear upon his head.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You speak for your kinsman the best, that ever I heard my lord.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: But I believe madam, my lord my cousin has not told you all my good parts.

sp.speaker: Tal:
sp.p: I told him so I warrant you cousin.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: What do you think he left out sir Giles?

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p:
Marry madam I can take tobacco now, and I have bought glowworms to kindle it withal, better
than all the burning glasses ith' world.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Glowworms sir Giles will they make it burn?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O odd madam I feed am with nothing but fire, a purpose, I'll be sworn they eat me five faggots a week in charcoal.

sp.speaker: Tal:
sp.p: Nay he has the strangest devices ladies that ever you heard I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Fur:
sp.p: That's a strange device in deed my lord.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: But your sowing sir Gyles is a more gentlewomanlike quality I assure you.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: O far away, for now servant, you need never marry, you are both husband, and wife yourself.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: Nay indeed mistress I wood fain marry for all that, and I'll tell you my reason, if you will.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: Let's hear it good servant.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: Why madam we have a great match at football towards, married men against bachelors, and the married men be all my friends, so I wood fain marry to take the married men's parts in truth.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: The best reason for marriage that ever I heard sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: I pray will you keep my work a little mistress; I must needs strain a little curtsy in truth.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: God's my life I thought he was a little to blame.

sp.speaker: Rud:
sp.p: Come, come, you hear not me dame.

sp.speaker: Fur:
sp.p: Well said sir cut, to her now we shall hear fresh courting.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: A 'las sir cut, you are not worth the hearing, everybody says you cannot love, howsoever you talk on't.

sp.speaker: Rud:
sp.p: Not love dame? 'slid what argument wouldst have of my love trow? let me look as red as scarlet a fore I see thee, and when thou com'st in sight if the sun of thy beauty, do not white me like a shepherd's holland I am a Jew to my creator.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O excellent.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Let me burst like a toad, if a frown of thy brow has not turned the very heart in my belly, and made me ready to be hanged by the heels for a fortnight to bring it to the right again.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You should have hanged longer sir cut: 'tis not right yet,

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Zonnes, bid me cut off the best limb of my body for thy love, and I'll lay't in thy hand to prove it, dost think I am no christian, have I not a soul to save?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Yes 'tis to save yet I warrant it, and will be while 'tis a soul if you use this.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Excellent courtship of all hands, only my captain's courtship, is not heard yet, good madam give him favour to court you with his voice.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: What should he court me with all else my lord?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Why, I hope madam there be other things to court ladies withal besides voices.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I mean with an audible sweet song madam.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: With all my heart my lord, if I shall be so much in debted to him.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Nay I will be indebted to your ears lady for hearing me sound music.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Well done captain, prove as it will now.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: My lord doctor Versey the physician is come to see master Clarence.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Light and attend him to him presently.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: To master Clarence? what is your friend sick?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Exceeding sick.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.p: I am exceeding sorry.

lg.l: Never was sorrow worthier bestowed
Than for the ill state of so good a man.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Alas poor gentleman; good my lord let's see him.

lg.l: Thanks gentle lady, but my friend is loath
to trouble ladies since he cannot quit them.
With any thing he hath that they respect.
Respect my lord; I wood hold such a man
In more respect than any emperor
For he could make me empress of myself
And in mine own rule comprehend the world.
How now young dame? what so inspired
This speech hath silver hairs, and reverence asks
And sooner shall have duty done of me
Then any pomp in temporal empery.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Good madam get my lord to let us greet him.

lg.l: Alas we shall but wrong and trouble him.
His contemplations greet him with most welcome.
I never knew a man of so sweet a temper
So soft and humble, of so high a spirit.
Alas my noble lord he is not rich,
Nor titles hath, nor in his tender cheeks
The standing lake of impudence corrupts,
Hath naught in all the world, nor naught wood have,
To grace him in the prostituted light.
But if a man wood consort with a soul
Where all man's sea of gall and bitterness
Is quite evaporate with 〈◊〉 holy flames,
And in whose powers a dovelike innocence
Fosters her own deserts, and life and death,
Runs hand in hand before them: all the skies
Clear and transparent to her piercing eyes,
Than wood my friend be something, but till then
A cipher, nothing, or the worst of men.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Sweet lord let's go visit him.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Pray good my lord, what's that you talk on?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Are you come from your necessary business sir Gyles? we talk of the visiting of my sick friend Clarence.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O good my lord let's visit him, cause I know his brother.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Know his brother, nay then count do
not deny him.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Pray my lord whether was eldest, he or his elder brother?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: O! the younger brother eldest, while you live sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I say so still my lord, but I am so born down with truth as never any knight ith' world was I think.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.p: A man wood think he speaks simply now; but indeed it is in the will of the parents, to make which child they will youngest, or eldest: for often we see the younger inherit, wherein he is eldest.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Your logical wit my lord is able to make any thing good.

lg.l: Well come sweet lords, and ladies, let us spend
The time till suppertime with some such sights
As my poor house is furnished withal
Pictures and jewels; of which implements
It may be I have some will please you much.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Sweet lord let's see them.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I think your disease sir, be rather of the mind then the body.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Be there diseases of the mind doctor?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: No question sir, even as there be of the body.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And cures for them too?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: And cures for them too, but not by physic.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You will have their diseases, griefs? will ye not?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Yes, oftentimes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And do not griefs ever rise out of passions?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Evermore.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And do not passions proceed from corporal distempers?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Not the passions of the mind, for the mind many times is sick, when the body is healthful.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But is not the minds-sickness of power to make the body sick?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: In time, certain.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And the bodies ill affections able to infect the mind?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: No question.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Then if there be such a natural commerce of powers betwixt them, that the ill estate of the one offends the other, why should not the medicines for one cure the other?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Yet it will not you see. Heimihi quod nullus amor est medicabilis herbis.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay then doctor, since you cannot make any reasonable connexion of these two contrarieties the mind and the body, making both subject to passion, wherein you confound the substances of both, I must tell you there is no disease of the mind but one, and that is ignorance.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Why what is love? is not that a disease of the mind?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nothing so for it springs naturally out of the blood, nor are we subject to any disease, or sorrow, whose causes or effects simply and natively concern the body, that the mind by any means partaketh, nor are there any passions in the soul, for where there are no affections, there are no passions: and affectus your master Galen refers parts irascents, for illic est anima sentiens ubi sunt affectus: therefore the rational soul cannot be there also.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: But you know we use to say, my mind gives me this or that, even in those addictions that concern the body.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: We use to say so indeed, and from that use comes the abuse of all knowledge, and her practice, for when the object in question only concerns the state of the body? why should the soul be sorry or glad for it? if she willingly mix herself, than she is a fool, if of necessity and against her will, a slave, and so, far from that wisdom, and freedom that the empress of reason, and an eternal substance should comprehend.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Divinely spoken sir, but very paradoxically.

div.stage: Enter Momford, Tales, Kingcob, Furnif; Rudes. Goosecap foul: Eugenia, Penelope, Hippolita, Winifrid.

lg.l: Who's there?
Ay, my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Bring hither the key of the gallery, methought I heard the doctor and my friend.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I did so sure.

lg.l: Peace then a while my lord
We will be bold to eavesdrop; for I know
My friend is as respective in his chamber
And by himself, of any thing he does
As in a critic synods curious eyes
Following therein Pythagoras' golden rule.
Maximè omnium teipsum reverere.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Know you the countess Eugenia sir?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Exceeding well sir, she's a good learned scholar.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Then I perceive you know her well indeed.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: methinks you two should use much conference.

lg.l: Alas sir, we do very seldom meet,
For her estate, and mine are so unequal,
And then her knowledge passeth mine so far
That I hold much to sacred a respect,
Of her high virtues to let mine attend them.
Pardon me sir, this humbleness cannot flow
Out of your judgement but from passion.
Indeed I do account that passion,
The very high perfection of my mind,
That is excited by her excellence,
And therefore willingly, and gladly feel it.
For what was spoken of the most chaste Queen
Of rich Pasiaca may be said of her.
Antevenit sortem moribus virtutibus annos,
Sex● animo, morum nobilitate genus.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: A most excellent distich.

lg.l: Come lords away, let's not presume too much
Of a good nature, not for all I have
Wood I have him take knowledge of the wrong
I rudely offer him: come then I'll show
A few rare jewels to your honoured eyes,
And then present you with a common supper.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: ●wells my lord, why is not this candlestick one of your jewels pray?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Yes marre is it sir Gyles if you will.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: 'Tis a most fine candlestick in truth, it wants nothing but the languages.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: The language's servant, why the languages?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Why mistress; there was a la●tin candlestick here afore, and that had the languages I am sure.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.p: I thought he had a reason for it lady.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I and a reason of the sun too my lord, for his father wood have been ashamed on't.

lg.l: Well master Clarence I perceive your mind
Hath so incorporate itself with flesh
And therein ratified that flesh to spirit,
That you have need of no physicians help.
But good sir even for holy virtue's health
And grace of perfect knowledge, do not make
Those groundworks of eternity, you lay
Means to your ruin, and short being here:
For the too strict and rational course you hold
Will eat your body up; and then the world,
Or that small point of it, where virtue lives
Will suffer diminution: it is now
Brought almost to a simple unity,
Which is, (As you well know) simplicior puncto.
And if that point fail once, why, then alas
The unity must only be supposed,
Let it not fail then, most men else have sold it;
Though you neglect yourself, uphold it,
So with my reverend love I leave you sir.
Thanks worthy doctor, I do amply quite you
I prop poor virtue, that am propped myself,
And only by one friend in all the world,
For virtues only sake I use this wile,
which otherwise I wood despise and scorn,
The world should sink and all the pomp she hugs
Close in her heart, in her ambitious gripe
Ere I sustain it, if this slenderest joint
Moved with the worth that worldlings love so well
Had power to save it from the throat of hell

div.stage: He draws the curtains and sits within them.

lg.l: Come on fair ladies I must make you both
Familiar witnesses of the most strange part
And full of impudence that ere I played.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What's that good madam?

lg.l: I that have been so more than maiden-nice
To my dear lord and uncle not to yield
By his importunate suit to his friends love
In look, or almost thought; will of myself
Far passed his expectation or his hope
In action, and in person greet his friend,
And comfort the poor gentleman's sick state.

sp.speaker: ` Pen.
sp.p: Is this a part of so much impudence?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: No but I fear me it will stretch to more

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Marry madam the more the merrier.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Marry madam? what should I marry him?

lg.l: You take the word methinks as though you would,
And if there be a thought of such kind heat
In your cold bosom, wood to God my breath
Might blow it to the flame of your kind heart.
God's precious lady, know ye what you say,
Respect you what I am, and what he is,
What the whole world wood say, and what great lords
I have refused and might as yet embrace,
And speak you like a friend, to wish me him?
Madam I cast all this, and know your choice
Can cast it quite out of the crystal doors
Of your judicial eyes: I am but young
And be it said without all pride I take,
to be a maid, I am one, and indeed
Yet in my mother's womb to all the wiles
Weaned in the looms of greatness, and of state:
And yet even by that little I have learned
Out of continual conference with you,
I have cried harvest home of thus much judgement
In my green sowing time, that I could place
The constant sweetness of good Clarence mind,
Filled with his inward wealth and nobleness;
(Look madam here,) when others outward trash
Should be contented to come under here.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: And so say I upon my maiden head.

lg.l: 'Tis well said ladies, thus we differ then,
I to the truth-wise, you to worldly men:
And now sweet dames observe an excellent jest
(At least in my poor jesting.) Th' Earl my uncle
Will miss me straight, and I know his close drift
Is to make me, and his friend Clarence meet
By some device or other he hath plotted.
Now when he seeks us round about his house
And cannot find us, for we may be sure
He will not seek me in his sick friends chamber,
(I have at all times made his love so strange,)
He straight will think, I went away displeased,
Or heartily careless of his heartiest suit.
And then I know there is no grief on earth
Will touch his heart so much, which I will suffer
To quite his late good pleasure wrought on me,
For I'll be sworn in motion and progress
Of his friend's suit, I never in my life
Wrestled so much with passion or was moved
To take his firm love in such jealous part.
This is most excellent madam, and will prove
A niecelike, and a noble friend's revenge.
Bold in a good cause, then let's greet his friend,
Where is this sickly gentleman at his book?
Now in good troth I wood these books were burned
that rap men from their friends before their time,
How does my uncle's friend, no other name
I need give him, to whom I give myself,
O madam let me rise that I may kneel,
And pay some duty to your sovereign grace.
Good Clarence do not work yourself disease
My lady comes to ease and comfort you.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: And we are handmaidens to her to that end.

lg.l: Ladies my heart will break, if it be held
Within the verge of this presumptuous chair.
Why, Clarence is your judgement bent to show
A common lover's passion? let the world,
That lives without a heart, and is but show,
Stand on her empty, and empoisoned form,
I know thy kindness, and have seen thy heart,
Cleft in my uncle's free, and friendly lips
And I am only now to speak and act,
The rites due to thy love: o I could weep ▪
A bitter show of tears for thy sick state,
I could give passion all her blackest rites.
And make a thousand vows to thy deserts,
But these are common, knowledge is the bond,
The seal and crown of our united minds ▪
And that is rare, and constant, and for that,
To my late written hand I give thee this,
See heaven, the soul thou gavest is in this hand.
This is the knot of our eternity,
Which fortune, death, nor hell, shall ever lose.

sp.speaker: Ia:
sp.p: What an unmannerly trick is this of thy countess, to give the noble count her uncle the slip thus?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Unmannerly, you villain? O that I were worthy to wear a dagger to any purpose for thy sake?

sp.speaker: Bul:
sp.p: Why young gentlemen, utter your anger with your fists.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: That cannot be man, for all fists are shut you know, and utter nothing, and besides I do not think my quarrel just for my lady's protection in this cause, for I protest she does most abominable miscarry herself.

sp.speaker: Ia:
sp.p: Protest you saucy Jack you, I should do my country and courtship good service to beat thy co●lts teeth out of thy head, for suffering such a reverend word to pass their guard; why, the oldest courtier in the world man, can do no more than protest,

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Indeed page if you were in France, you wood be broken upon a wheel for it, there is not the best Duke's son in France dares say I protest, till he be one and thirty year old at least, for the inheritance of that word is not to be possessed before.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Well, I am sorry for my presumption then, but more sorry for my ladies, marry most sorry for thee good lord Momford, that will make us most of all sorry for ourselves, if we do not find her out.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why alas what should we do? all the stars of our heaven see, we seek her as fast as we can, if she be crept into a rush we will seek her out or burn her.

lg.l: Villains where are your ladies, seek them
Out; hence, home ye monsters, nad still keep you thereexeunt ▪ pages.
Where levity keeps, in her in constant sphere,
A away you precious villains, what a plague,
Of varried tortures is a woman's heart?
How like a peacock's tail with different lights,
They differ from themselves; the very air
Alters the aspen humours of their bloods.
Now excellent good, now superexcellent bad.
Some excellent good, some? but one of all:
Wood any ignorant baby serve her friend,
Such an uncivil part? 'sblood what is learning?
An artificial cobweb to catch flies,
And nourish spiders, could she cut my throat,
W. with her departure I had been her calf,
And made a dish at supper for my guests
Of her kind charge, I am beholding to her,
Puff, is there not a feather in this air
A man may challenge for her? what? A feather?
So easy to be seen; so apt to trace;
In the weak flight of her unconstant wings?
A mote man at the most, that with the sun,
Is only seen, yet with his radiant eye,
We cannot single so from other motes,
To say this mote is she, passion of death,
She wrongs me passed a death, come ▪ come my friend,
Is mine, she not her own, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Come uncle shall we go to supper now?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Zounds to supper? what a do●r is this?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: A 'las what ails my uncle, ladies see.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Is not your lordship well?

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: Good speak my lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: A sweet plague on you all, ye witty rogues have you no pity in your villainous jests, but run a man quite from his fifteen wits?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Will not your lordship see your friend, and niece?

lg.l: Wood I might sink if I shame not to see her
Tush was a passion of pure jealousy,
I'll now make her now amends with adoration.
God's of learning and of constancy,
Of friendship and every other virtue.
Come, come, you have abused me now I know
And now you plaster me with flatteries.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: My lord the contract is knit fast betwixt them

lg.l: Now all heaven's choir of angels sing amen,
And bless the●s true born nuptials with their bliss,
And niece though you have cozened me in this,
I'll uncle you yet in another thing,
And quite deceive your expectation.
For where you think you have contracted hearts
With a poor gentleman, he is sole heir
To all my earldom, which to you and yours
I freely, and for ever here bequeath;
Call forth the lords, sweet ladies let them see
This sudden and most welcome novelty;
But cry you mercy niece, perhaps your modesty
Will not have them partake this sudden match.
O uncle think you so, I hope I made
My choice with too much judgement to take shame
Of any form I shall perform it with.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Said like my niece, and worthy of my friend.

div.stage: Enter Furnifal, Tal: King: Goosecap Rud: foul: Ia: Will, Bullaker.

lg.l: My lords, take witness of an absolute wonder,
A marriage made for virtue, only virtue,
My friend, and my dear niece are man and wife.
A wonder of mine honour, and withal
A worthy precedent for all the world;
Heaven bless you for it lady, and your choice.

sp.speaker: Ambo
sp.p: Thanks my good lord.

lg.l: An accident that will make policy blush,
And all the compliments of wealth and state,
In the successful and unnumbered race
That shall flow from it, filled with fame and grace.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: So may it speed dear countess, worthy Clarence.

sp.speaker: Ambo
sp.p: Thanks good sir Cutberd.

lg.l: Captain be not dismayed, I'll marry thee,
For while we live, thou shalt my consort be.
By France my lord, I am not grieved a whit,
Since Clarence hath her; he hath been in France,
And therefore merits her if she were better.
Then knights I'll knit your happy nuptial knots,
I know the lady's minds better than you;
Though my rare niece hath chose for virtue only,
Yet some more wise than some, they choose for both
Virtue, and wealth.
Nay uncle than I plead
This goes with my choice, some more wise than some,
For only virtue's choice is truest wisdom.
Take wealth, and virtue both amongst you then,
They love ye knights extreamely, and sir cut:
I give the chaste Hippolita to you ▪
Sir Gyles this lady;
Nay stay there my lord,
I have not yet proved all his knightly parts
I hear he is an excellent poet too.
That I forgotten sweet lady; good sir Gyles ▪
Have you no sonnet of your pen about ye?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Yes, that I have I hope my lord my cousin.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why, this is passing fit.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I'd be loath to go without paper about me against my mistress, hold my work again, a man knows not what need he shall have perhaps.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Well remembered a mine honour sir Gyles:

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Pray read my lord, I made this sonnet of my mistress.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Nay read thyself man.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: No intruth sir cut: I cannot read mine own hand.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Well I will read it.

lg.l: Three things there be which thou shouldst only crave,
Thou pomeroy, or thou apple of mine eye;
Three things there be, which thou shouldst long to have,
And for which three, each modest dame wood cry,
Three things there be, that should thine anger suage,
An English mastiff, and a fine French page.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: 'Sblood ass, there's but two things, thou sham'st thyself.
Why sir Cutt: that's 〈◊〉, the verse wood have been too long, and I had put in the third, 'slight you are no poet I perceive.

sp.speaker: Pe●.
sp.p: 'Tis excellent servant.

lg.l: Keep it lady then,
And take the only knight of mortal men.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Thank you good my lord as much as though you had given me twenty shillings in truth, now I may take the married men's parts at football.

lg.l: All comforts crown you all; and you captain
For merry form's sake let the willow crown;
A wreath of willow bring us hither straight.
Not for a world should that have been forgotten
Captain it is the fashion, take this crown.
With all my heart my lord, and thank ye too
I will thank any man that gives me crowns.

sp.speaker: Mom.

lg.l: Now will we consecrate our ready supper
To honoured Hymen as his nuptial rite,
In form whereof first dance fair lords and ladies
And after sing, so we will sing and dance,
And to the skies our virtuous joys advance.

sp.p: Now to the song, and do this garland grace.

lg.head: Canto.
lg.l: Willow, willow, willow. ▪
Our captain goes down:
Willow, willow, willow,
His valour doth crown.
The rest with rosemary we grace,
Oh Hymen let thy lights
With richest rays guild every face,
And feast hearts with delights.
Willow, willow, willow,
We chant to the skies:
And with black and yellows,
Give courtship the prize.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
